questions.question: What is the difference between <ol> and <ul> tags?
options: <ol> creates unordered lists, <ul> creates ordered lists
<ol> creates ordered lists (numbered), <ul> creates unordered lists (bulleted)
<ol> is for tables, <ul> is for lists
questions.explanation: <ol> (ordered list) creates numbered lists, while <ul> (unordered list) creates bulleted lists. Both require <li> tags for each list item.

questions.question: Which tag is used to define individual items in a list?
questions.explanation: The <li> (list item) tag is used to define individual items within both ordered (<ol>) and unordered (<ul>) lists.

questions.question: What are 'compound tags' in the context of lists and tables?
options: Tags that only work in conjunction with one another
Tags that don't need closing tags
questions.explanation: Compound tags are tags that work together. For lists, you need <ol> or <ul> to define the list and <li> for each item. For tables, you need multiple tags like <table>, <tr>, and <td> working together.

questions.question: Which tag is used to define a table row?
questions.explanation: The <tr> (table row) tag is used to define a row in an HTML table. Each <tr> contains one or more <td> (table data) or <th> (table header) cells.

questions.question: Which tag is used to define a table cell (data cell)?
questions.explanation: The <td> (table data) tag is used to define a standard cell in an HTML table. It contains the actual data/content of the cell.

questions.question: What is the correct structure for creating a table in HTML?
questions.explanation: The correct structure is: <table> contains <tr> (table rows), and each <tr> contains <td> (table data cells) or <th> (table header cells).

questions.question: Which tag is used to define a table header cell?
questions.explanation: The <th> (table header) tag is used to define header cells in a table. Header cells are typically bold and centered, and help describe the data in the columns or rows.
